GRANT AND PROJECT SUMMARY

Environment  The environmental classification of the project is category B. The 
Assessment  project will improve the quality of the environment and the living 
standards of communities in small towns in the Lao PDR. The 
expected benefits include availability of house-connected clean 
and reliable water supply for drinking and sanitation, minimized or 
eliminated flooding and stagnation of wastewater, and improved 
personal  sanitation.  The  results  of  the  initial  environmental 
examinations indicate that the subprojects are unlikely to cause 
significant adverse environmental impact. The potential adverse 
environmental  impact  associated  with  the  design,  construction, 
and operation of the subprojects will be mostly of low magnitude 
and  localized,  and  can  be  readily  mitigated  through  proper 
engineering design and the implementation of the mitigation and 
monitoring  measures  identified  in  the  initial  environmental 
examinations. 
   
Project Description  The project will improve the quality of life of residents in small 
towns in the Lao PDR and make the small towns better able to 
function  as  market,  services,  and  manufacturing  centers 
supporting  the  rural  hinterlands.  The  project  will  support  the 
government’s National Growth and Poverty Eradication Strategy 
(NGPES 2004), which is aimed at reducing poverty through strong 
economic growth and increased emphasis on the poorest districts. 
 
The outcomes of the project will be (i) improved access, quality, 
reliability, and sustainability of water supply services in about 12 
small towns in the northern and central regions of the country; and 
(ii) improved living conditions in the small towns through urban 
and village environmental improvements.  
   
Rationale  Residents in small towns in the Lao PDR spend considerable 
time, energy, and financial resources getting water for their daily 
needs.  Low  coverage  of  safe  piped  water  supply,  poor 
environmental conditions, and low hygiene awareness in small 
towns have resulted in a high incidence of diarrhea and malaria, 
and high morbidity. Such unfavorable conditions also constrain 
the small towns’ economic development and their ability to serve 
the  surrounding  rural  hinterlands.  The  project  supports  water 
supply and associated urban improvement in small towns, the

ii 
government’s highest priorities in small town development. The 
geographic focus of the project is the poor Northern Region, in 
line with the geographic focus of Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
operations,  and  the  Central  Region.  The  project  includes 
significant community participation, poverty reduction, and health 
and hygiene promotion activities to strengthen local ownership of 
the project facilities and maximize the intended health benefits 
and poverty reduction impact. 
 
The  project  implementation  follows  a  phased  approach,  with 
phase 1 covering three towns, phase 2 five towns, and phase 3 
four towns. Supplementary financing is required to finance the 
projected outputs in four phase 3 towns, which cannot be covered 
by the original budget because of cost increases in the phase 1 
and  2  towns.  The  costs  have  increased  because  (i) larger 
populations  will  be  served  by  the  infrastructure,  given  a 
higher-than-assumed growth rate and a revised design horizon; 
and (ii) increased per capita water demand has increased. 
The project implementation progress is found to be satisfactory 
and it is expected that the supplementary financing will heighten 
the project’s impact by improving the quality of life of an additional 
44,000 residents in the four target towns in the Lao PDR. The 
proposed project towns were selected according to the subproject 
selection criteria agreed on under the project.  
   
Impact and Outcome  The project’s impact will be a better quality of life for residents in 
small  towns  in  the  Lao  PDR  and  increased  capacity  of  small 
towns to function as market, services, and manufacturing centers 
supporting the rural hinterlands. The outcomes of the project will 
be  (i) more  accessible,  better-quality,  reliable,  and  sustainable 
water supply services; and (ii) improved environmental conditions 
in  the  small  towns.  These  outcomes  will  be  achieved  through 
(i) the construction of new water supply systems using appropriate 
technologies; (ii) the rehabilitation and improvement of selected 
urban  facilities,  i.e.,  sanitation,  drainage,  roads,  and  bridges; 
(iii) the  promotion  of  public  hygiene  awareness  and  public 
participation  in  village  improvement  initiatives;  and 
(iv) the strengthening  of  sector  capacity  to  plan,  manage,  and 
regulate water supply and sanitation facilities and services. 
   
Project Investment Plan   The investment cost of the project is estimated at $32.1 million, 
including taxes and duties of $2.7 million.  
   
Financing Plan  It  is  proposed  that  ADB  provide  a  supplementary  grant  of 
$6.6 million  from  its  Asian  Development  Fund  resources.  The 
government will finance the taxes and duties and the resettlement 
costs. Asian Development Fund grant financing for the project is 
justified:  (i) the  sector’s  investment  demand  is  huge  but  the 
government is in a very difficult fiscal situation, (ii) water supply 
and  sanitation  are  basic  human  needs,  (iii) the  project  will

iii 
contribute  to  achieving  the  Millennium  Development  Goals, 
(iv) the  project  has  potential  for  significant  poverty  reduction 
impact,  and  (v) the  government  is  strongly  committed  to 
developing the sector.

environmental improvements, which will have a direct impact on 
the health and lives of the people in the town communities. The 
health benefits will come from (i) a safe and convenient water 
supply;  (ii) improved  environmental  sanitation  through  drainage 
and  related  works;  (iii) increased  use  of  domestic  sanitation 
facilities  due  to  increased  awareness,  appropriate  sanitation 
models, and improved water supply; (iv) increased knowledge and

from physical investments under the project will be complemented

by  the  hygiene  awareness  and  promotion  activities.  The  core 
villages in the four project towns will benefit directly from improved 
access roads, footpaths, drainage, and sanitation in residential 
areas. The towns’ economies will benefit from greater productivity 
as  a  result  of  health  improvement,  time  savings  in  collecting 
water,  and  increased  urban  efficiency  arising  from  improved 
roads, bridges, drainage, and sanitation. Residents in towns will 
also  benefit  from  lower  water  costs  and  from  savings  in

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
supplementary grant to the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) for the Northern and 
Central Regions Water Supply and Sanitation Project. The design and monitoring framework is 
in Appendix 1. 
II.  THE APPROVED PROJECT 
 
2.  The Northern and Central Regions Water Supply and Sanitation Sector Project1 was 
approved on 25 August 2005 for an amount of $24.9 million equivalent, of which $10 million was 
to be financed with a grant from the Asian Development Bank (ADB). This grant took effect on 
14 June 2006 and the activities began in November 2006. The approved project is scheduled to 
be completed in March 2010 and the initial grant to be closed in September 2010. 
 
A.  Project Rationale 
 
3.  The government’s National Growth and Poverty Eradication Strategy (NGPES 2004) is 
aimed at reducing poverty through strong economic growth and increased emphasis on the 
poorest districts. It is focused on health, including water supply and sanitation, as one of four 
priority sectors for poverty reduction. Having been neglected in past investments, small towns 
with populations ranging from 2,000 to 20,000 remain underdeveloped—overall piped water 
supply service coverage is only about 17%, compared with 69% in Vientiane and the four 
largest secondary towns. More than 50% of households do not have any form of water-sealed 
toilets, and less than 10% of primary schools have latrines. Roads have mainly gravel or dirt 
pavements, with low coverage of roadside drains. Residents in small towns spend considerable 
time, energy, and financial resources getting water for their daily needs. Low coverage of safe 
piped water supply, poor environmental conditions, and low hygiene awareness in small towns 
have resulted in a high incidence of diarrhea and malaria, and high morbidity. Such unfavorable 
conditions also constrain the small towns’ economic development and their ability to serve the 
surrounding  rural  hinterlands.  The  project  supports  water  supply  and  associated  urban 
improvement in small towns, the government’s highest priorities in small town development. The 
geographic focus of the project is the poor Northern Region, in line with the geographic focus of 
ADB  operations,  and  the  Central  Region.  The  project  includes  significant  community 
participation, poverty reduction, and health and hygiene promotion activities to strengthen local 
ownership of the facilities and maximize the intended health benefits and poverty reduction 
impact. 
 
B.  Objectives and Scope 
 
4.  The project’s impact will be a better quality of life for residents in small towns in the 
Lao PDR  and  the  improved  capacity  of  small  towns  to  function  as  market,  services,  and 
manufacturing centers supporting the rural hinterlands. The outcomes of the project will be 
(i) improved access, quality, reliability, and sustainability of water supply services in about 12 
small  towns  in  the  Northern  and  Central  regions  of  the  country;  and  (ii) improved  living 
conditions in the small towns through urban and village environmental improvements. The 
objectives will be achieved through (i) the constructing new optimal-size water supply systems 
using appropriate technologies; (ii) the rehabilitation or improvement of selected urban facilities,

absorptive capacity of sector institutions. The targeted beneficiaries in the 12 towns will number

D.  Status and Progress of Project Implementation 
 
1.  Implementation Progress 
 
7.  The overall progress by June 2009 was estimated at 59%, compared with an elapsed 
implementation period of 83%. The delay occurred mainly at the start of the project and was due 
to delay in grant effectiveness and in the recruitment of consultants.5 The progress of the 
construction works generally follows the planned schedule. 
 
8.  The project is formulated as a sector project, and will have five outputs: (i) strengthened 
regulation and management of the water supply sector; (ii) water supply development; (iii) urban 
environmental  improvements;  (iv) participation,  awareness,  and  community  actions;  and 
(v) project  implementation  assistance  and  capacity  building.  The  implementation  follows  a 
phased approach, with phase 1 covering three towns, phase 2 five towns, and phase 3 four 
towns.6 The progress for each output is summarized below. 
 
2.  Output 1: Strengthened Water Supply Sector Regulation and Management 
 
9.  The activities are focused on strengthening the position of the water supply regulatory 
committee7 (WSRC) as regulatory authority and strengthening the capacity of the water supply 
division of MPWT to plan water supply investments and to guide the operation and maintenance 
of infrastructure. 
 
10.  As a result of ADB’s continuing policy dialogue with the government, the scope of this 
output  was  extended  in  2008  to  include  the  corporatization  of  four  PNPs:  Luangprabang, 
Louang-Namtha, Oudomxai, and Xaignabouli. The corporatization was expected to transform 
the  public  PNPs  into  more  efficient,  commercially  oriented,  and  autonomous  water  supply 
companies. The project supports the development of the PNPs’ capacity for business and 
financial management, commercial orientation, and operating efficiency.  
 
11.  In February 2009, ADB approved the Small Towns Water Supply and Sanitation Sector 
Project,8 which included other activities to further strengthen the sector, such as establishing the 
WSRC as a sustainable independent agency, updating the water sector investment plan, and

12.  Progress. This output addresses the specific lessons learned from the Water Supply 
and Sanitation Sector Project,9 which was closed in 2007: lack of effective sector coordination

financial sustainability of PNPs; and low awareness of PNPs and the provincial governors of 
their obligations under the loan agreement.  
 
13.  Satisfactory progress has been made in addressing these issues: 
  
(i)  In June 2009, the National Assembly passed the new water law, which includes 
new  guidelines  on  water  tariff  setting  and  lays  down  basic  principles  and 
measures, including regulation, for water supply management. This law will guide 
officials  in  planning,  designing,  building,  managing,  and  using  water  supply 
facilities effectively.  
(ii)  Tariffs are being adjusted in accordance with the cost recovery principles laid out 
in the grant agreement, and tariffs were increased on 1 April 2009.10 Although the 
PNPs have not yet formally reported any financial performance data,11 some 
PNPs have reported positive cash flow returns and are preparing investment 
programs financed with their internally generated income. 
(iii)  All  but  one  PNP  have  signed  the  MOA,  which  basically  allows  the  PNP  to 
operate the government-owned assets following enterprise law and sets out the 
roles and responsibilities of the PNP and the OPG. Specific subsidiary loan 
agreements are signed by PNPs and Ministry of Finance. Of the four phase 3 
towns, only the MOA for Nam Keung in Bokeo province still has to be signed. 
The signing of the MOA is a condition for disbursement. 
(iv)  Four of the PNPs have submitted corporate plans, of which two have been 
translated and are being reviewed by the project consultants. Furthermore, they 
have adopted an arrears collection strategy and allocated sufficient staff training 
budgets, and they maintain a depreciation account.

financing mechanism of this agency12 is still under consideration by the government. Approval 
was delayed by the reorganization of the regulatory agency and the proposal of a new water 
law. ADB will follow up the approval of the financing mechanism through continuous dialogue.

3.  Output 2: Water Supply Development 
 
16.  This output is focused on the development of safe, affordable, and reliable piped water 
supply  systems  for  about  100,000  residents  in  12  project  towns  by  2015.  It  includes  the 
development  of  (i) surface,  spring,  or  groundwater  sources;  (ii) raw  water  transmission 
pipelines; (iii) water treatment facilities; (iv) distribution networks; (v) treated-water reservoirs; 
(vi) individual metered service connections; and (vii) an office/workshop/store for each PNP 
branch. It covers the procurement of equipment for O&M of the water supply systems. 
 
17.  Progress. Works in phase 1 towns were completed in October 2009 and the works in 
phase 2 towns are under construction, to be completed by August 2010. Detailed designs are 
being prepared for the phase 3 towns. 
 
18.  The Water Supply and Sanitation Sector Project (footnote 4) also showed that high 
connection charges up-front lead to low connection rates. Although the project design provided 
for deferred payment, at inception it was agreed that all up-front charges would be scrapped 
and connection costs would be charged through the depreciation component of the water tariffs. 
This policy has led to uptakes of about 92% on average, substantially increasing the revenue 
stream and improving the financial performance of the PNPs.  
 
4.  Output 3: Urban Environmental Improvements 
 
19.  This  output  is  focused  on  the  rehabilitation  and  improvement  of  small  urban 
infrastructure  directly  associated  with  the  construction  and  operation  of  the  water  supply 
systems,  including  public  sanitation  facilities,  drainage,  roads,  and  culverts.  It  covers  the 
procurement of equipment for O&M of the rehabilitated or improved urban facilities. 
 
20.  Progress. Works in phase 1 towns were to be completed by December 2009. Works in 
phase 2 towns have been designed but have not yet been tendered, while works in phase 3

34.  The supplementary financing will heighten the impact of the project by improving the

sanitation coverage in target communities to 65% of households in 2017. The proposed project

36.  The proposed supplementary grant will support the following three outputs: 
 
(i)  New water supply systems. New water supply systems will be built in each of

(ii)  Improved  roads,  culverts,  drainage,  and  sanitation.  In  each  of  the  four

37.  The proposal to provide supplementary financing is justified since it complements the 
ongoing initiatives in the water supply and sanitation sector in the Lao PDR and specifically

Regions  Water  Supply  and  Sanitation  Sector  Project.  This  project  has  made  satisfactory 
progress with regard to sector reform and infrastructure development, and is likely to achieve its 
expected outcome.  
 
38.  For  each  of  the  four  project  towns  full  feasibility  studies  have  been  prepared

management requirements. The subprojects have been found to be efficient and affordable to 
the beneficiaries. The per capita investments costs vary from $100 to $190 for the four project

required water tariffs are in line with the WSRC-recommended tariffs.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACT, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
 
58.  Socioeconomic  benefits.  The  supplementary  financing  will  benefit  about  44,000 
residents (by 2027) in the towns Namkeung, Namor, Namtha, and Ngoi, by providing safe and 
reliable piped water supply and urban environmental improvements that will have a direct 
impact on the health and lives of the people in the town communities. The health benefits will 
come from (i)  safe and convenient water supply; (ii) improved environmental sanitation through 
drainage and related works; (iii) increased use of domestic sanitation facilities due to increased 
awareness,  appropriate  sanitation  models,  and  improved  water  supply;  (iv) increased 
knowledge and awareness of health and hygiene issues; and (v) avoidance of the drudgery 
associated with collecting water. The health benefits from the physical investments will be 
complemented by the hygiene awareness and promotion activities. The core villages in the four 
project towns will benefit directly from VEIs, providing access roads, footpaths, and improved 
drainage and sanitation in residential areas. The towns’ economies will benefit from enhanced 
productivity as a result of health improvement, time savings in collecting water, and increased 
urban efficiency due to improved roads, bridges, drainage, and sanitation. Residents in towns 
will also benefit from lower water costs and from savings in health-care costs. 
 
59.  A social analysis was carried out during project appraisal and a poverty reduction and 
social  strategy,  a  gender  strategy,  and  all  required  safeguard  documents,  including  a 
resettlement framework and an ethnic groups development framework, have been prepared. 
These documents are applicable to the works to be financed by the proposed supplementary 
financing. The poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 6.  
 
60.  Gender impact. While both men and women will benefit from the project activities, 
women will benefit more in terms of time savings, reduced drudgery, and improved family 
health. Women perform the bulk of household work with the help of children, particularly girls. 
They are generally responsible for water collection, family hygiene and sanitation, and the care 
of sick family members. The construction of new public toilet facilities will take into consideration 
specific gender needs, particularly the privacy needs of women. Particular attention will be given 
to involving women in employment, decision making, learning, and training activities under the 
project. For instance, qualified women will be eligible for at least 30% of new jobs generated by 
the project in the community (i.e., O&M of community-based initiatives). A gender strategy for 
the project is in Appendix 7. 
 
61.  Land acquisition and resettlement. The adverse impact from LAR will be insignificant. 
Only 12 households will experience major impact;14 of these, two will need resettlement. About 
525 households will incur temporary losses, for which they will be compensated if eligible. The 
summary resettlement plan is in Appendix 8 and short resettlement plans are included in the 
appraisal reports on the subprojects (Supplementary Appendixes A–D).  
 
62.  Environmental  impact.  In  accordance  with  the  project’s  category B  environmental 
classification (nonsensitive), IEEs have been carried out for each of the subprojects. The IEEs 
showed  no  significant  adverse  impact.  Potential  negative  impact  will  occur  mainly  during 
construction and will be temporary, minor, and localized in extent and can be mitigated to 
acceptable levels. The summary IEE is in Appendix 9 and IEEs are included in the appraisal 
reports on the subprojects (Supplementary Appendixes A–D).  
 
                                                 
14 Households that will experience major impact are those that will be (i) physically displaced from housing, or (ii) lose 
more than 10% of their income source, or (iii) lose more than 40% of their residential structure.

63.  Economic and financial benefits. For the four subproject towns, the economic internal 
rate of return has been calculated for the water supply works and the urban environmental 
improvement works. The economic opportunity cost of capital is 12% in real terms. The results 
show that the economic internal rate of return varies from 19% to 26% for the water supply 
works, and 13% to 22% for the urban environmental improvement works, making the works 
economically viable. 
 
64.  The financial analysis shows that the agreed financial objectives of cost recovery (i.e., 
full O&M cost and gradually increasing portion of annual depreciation) and debt service (not less 
than 1.2 times) for the sector can be met. The attainment of the financial objectives, however, 
will  require  tariffs  to  be  periodically  raised  in  line  with  the  Water  Supply  Authority’s 
recommendations  and  to  keep  pace  with  inflation.  The  summary  financial  and  economic 
analysis is in Appendix 10, and detailed financial and economic analyses are included in the 
appraisal reports on the subprojects (Supplementary Appendixes A–D).  
 
65.  Risks. The main risks associated with the additional works are (i) the limited human 
resources and institutional capacities in the provinces and districts; (ii) uncertainty regarding 
tariff  increases  necessary  to  ensure  sustainability  of  water  supply  services;  (iii) insufficient 
community  participation  in  project  implementation,  particularly  from  women  and  the  poor; 
(iv) adverse effects of resettlement on poor and vulnerable households; (v) inadequate time and 
resources for assessing raw water; and (vi) inadequate sources for O&M of project facilities.  
 
66.  The  project  incorporates  measures  to  mitigate  those  risks.  The  measures  include 
(i) capacity building for the PIU and for the communication, transport, posts, and construction 
offices and water supply and sanitation offices, to strengthen their managerial and operational 
capacities;  (ii) commitment  to  tariff  reforms  and  associated  assurances  by  the  respective 
provincial governments; (iii) a participation program, gender strategy, and public awareness 
campaigns; (iv) a resettlement framework and resettlement plans to ensure that all affected 
people will at least maintain or improve their living standards after project completion; and 
(v) local ownership intensified through community participation in designing, implementing, and 
maintaining  the  facilities  and  the  provincial  government’s  commitment  to  adequate  budget 
allocation for O&M.

DEVELOPMENT COORDINATION 
 
A.  Major Development Partners: Strategic Foci and Key Activities  
 
1.  Several  development  partners  provide  assistance  to  the  urban  water  supply  and 
sanitation sector. The Northern and Central Region Water Supply and Sanitation Sector Project 
(the project) is supported by ADB, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries Fund 
for  International  Development  (OFID),  Norwegian  Agency  for  Development  Cooperation 
(NORAD), and United Nations Human Settlements Programme (UN-HABITAT).  
 
2.  A French water utility (SEDIF) promotes private investment in the urban water supply 
and through a nonprofit association, the Research and Technological Exchange Group (GRET), 
which provides output-based subsidies targeted at the poor. GRET is assisting the Ministry of 
Public Works and Transport (MPWT) to implement private water supply concessions.  
 
3.  NORAD has provided substantial assistance to develop the capacity of the Water Supply 
Regulatory Committee and the Water Supply Department of MPWT, and has been a key partner 
for previous and ongoing ADB projects.  
 
4.  Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency  (JICA)  has  provided  funds  to  develop 
Vientiane’s water system and assistance in building the capacity of PNPs.  
 
5.  Agence Française de Développement (AFD) has also supported capacity development 
for PNPs through the construction of the Waterworks Technology Training Center in Vientiane 
and development of training courses.  
 
6.  UN-HABITAT  is  assisting  MPWT  to  develop  community-based  piped  water  supply 
schemes in small towns.  
 
7.  The World Bank’s WSP-EAP, United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF), the World 
Health Organization (WHO), and UN-HABITAT are key partners in hygiene awareness and 
promotion in communities and schools. ADB and the International Finance Cooperation (IFC) 
are also working with the Government to implement the Enterprise Law and the World Bank and 
the IFC are supporting State Owned Enterprises governance and reform. 
 
B.  Institutional Arrangements and Processes for Development Coordination  
 
8.   Since the mid 1990s ADB has been and continues to be the dominant development 
partner in the water supply and sanitation sector. Through its partnership with the Government, 
a sector investment plan and sector policy was developed in the late 1990s, which provided 
guidance for the Government and other development partners on how the sector could be 
funded and developed.  
 
9.  Furthermore, sector coordination takes place when preparing new projects, through 
individual  meetings  or  workshops.  Nevertheless,  due  to  the  relatively  small  number  of 
development partners involved in the sector, this coordination has proven to be effective. The 
project itself forms a solid basis for sector coordination itself, since several partners are directly 
involved in its implementation. 
 
C.  Achievements, Issues and Recommendations 
 
10.  Although ADB has been by far the largest and most endurable development partner, 
other partners and agencies have had some involvement in the sector from time to time.

Although JICA and AFD have made quite sizable investments, other donors have generally 
provided assistance on a much smaller scale and generally aimed at smaller communities. ADB 
in partnership with NORAD has worked almost exclusively with the Government on a successful 
program of sector reform.  
 
11.  In more recent times, and especially with the enactment of the Water Supply Law and 
Enterprise Law, the Government recognized the need for structural sector coordination, led by 
the government. The  recently approved Small Towns Water Supply and Sanitation Sector

D.  Screening of Potential Impact and Mitigation Measures 
 
5.  The four subprojects will supply about 40,000 people with 120 liters of water per capita 
per day by 2027. Raw water sources have been considered for each town. The potential 
environmental impact associated with the design, construction, and operation of the water supply 
system includes: (i) specific impact related to the location of the water treatment facilities and 
pipeline routes, (ii) availability and quality of water sources, (iii) discharge of wastewater and sludge 
and  their  impact  on  the  receiving  water,  and  (iv) increased  wastewater  from  the  connected

sedimentation and filtration processes, and the sedimentation sludge may contain small traces 
of nontoxic treatment plant chemicals. In most cases, the expected sludge volumes will be 
negligible compared with the overall minimum dry-season flow in the receiving river. The sludge

effluent standards and avoid adverse impact on surface water resources.

projected financial performance of the PNPs for the period 2009–2016 indicate that the PNPs 
are projected to earn positive net income each year over the forecast period. More than 100% of 
annual depreciation expense (historical cost) is recovered during the forecast period. The PNPs

  5.  Sustainability 
 
6.  The economic sustainability of the subprojects depends on the subproject’s financial 
sustainability. Unless the subproject is financially sustainable, the economic benefits assumed 
in the analysis will not materialize. The projected financial performances for the subprojects 
have shown that the agreed upon financial objectives of cost recovery (i.e., full O&M cost and 
gradually increasing portion of annual depreciation) and debt service (not less than 1.2 times) 
for the sector could be met. Meeting the financial objectives of the sector indicates subproject 
financial sustainability. The attainment of the financial objectives, however, would require that 
tariffs are periodically raised in line with WSRC’s recommendations and to keep pace with 
inflation. 
 
B.  Economic Analysis 
   
1.  Introduction 
 
7.  Economic  analyses  for  the  water  supply  and  urban  environmental  improvement 
components in the four district towns constituting phase 3 of the project were undertaken in 
accordance with the ADB’s Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects, 3 Guidelines for 
the  Economic  Analysis  of  Water  Supply  Projects,4 and  Framework  for  the  Economic  and 
Financial Appraisal of Urban Development Sector Projects.5  
 
8.  The incremental capital and operation and maintenance (O&M) costs for each water 
supply and urban environmental improvement component were estimated and are expressed in 
constant February 2009 prices in Lao kip. All costs were derived from the financial project costs 
and re-expressed in economic prices using the domestic price numeraire. Taxes and duties 
were  deducted  as  appropriate  from  base  costs.  Tradable  components  were  adjusted  to 
economic prices using a shadow exchange rate factor of 1.05 while non-traded components 
were valued at domestic market prices. A shadow wage rate factor of 0.71 for unskilled labor 
was applied to reflect its opportunity cost in the context of wide availability of labor in the Lao 
People’s Democratic Republic. Subproject components are assumed to have useful economic 
life of 25 years; the mechanical and electrical equipment of the components are assumed to 
have useful economic life of 5 years. 
 
  2.  Demand Forecast 
 
9.  Water demand in the district towns was derived from the current population within the 
planned service area, population growth, current and future domestic water consumption levels,

  3.  Least-Cost Analysis 
 
10.  Least-cost analysis was undertaken to evaluate different technical options, including 
alternative  water  sources,  the  size  and  timing  of  water  treatment  plants,  reservoirs,  and 
transmission mains. The analysis compares various technical alternatives with similar or equal 
estimated benefits. The alternative with the lowest NPV is recommended for engineering design 
and benefit-cost analysis. 
 
  4.  Economic Benefits 
 
11.  The principal benefits that would be derived from the development of a system of piped, 
treated  water  include  improved  accessibility,  convenience  and  reliability  of  water  supply, 
increased  quantities  of  water  and  improved  water  quality,  and  greater  health  benefits. 
Quantifiable economic benefits of improved water supply services include (i) benefits from 
non-incremental water consumption, valued at the weighted average supply price of water from 
non-piped sources; (ii) incremental water consumption, valued at average demand price; and 
(iii) other resource savings. The weighted average water supply costs of existing water sources 
are estimated at KN12,103 per m3 in Namkheung, KN13,181 per m3 in Namor, KN9,117 per m3 
in Namtha and KN11,966 per m3 in Ngoi. The average demand price is estimated at KN8,151 
per m3 in Namkheung, KN8,465 per m3 in Namor, KN6,208 per m3 in Namtha and KN6,958 per 
m3 in Ngoi. Health benefits, likely to occur provided that the adverse health impact of an 
increased volume of wastewater can be minimized, have not been quantified and included in the 
analysis due to lack of reliable data. 
 
12.  The  urban  environmental  improvement  component  will  significantly  improve  the 
environmental and living conditions and public health in the subproject areas. The improvement 
in the environment may be reflected in the amounts people are willing to pay for property either 
in terms of rent or the purchase price of the property in the subproject areas. In Namkheung, 
Namor, Namtha, and Ngoi subproject areas, existing land values amount to KN50,000 per m2, 
KN90,000 per m2, KN80,000 per m2, and KN70,000 per m2, respectively, as provided by their 
respective town officials. The respective town officials estimate that the increase in land value 
as a result of the subprojects would be about 25%. 
 
  5.  Results of Economic Analysis 
 
13.  The results of the economic internal rate of return calculation of the subprojects, as 
shown  below,  are  well  above  the  economic  opportunity  cost  of  capital  of  12%.  It  can  be 
concluded that the proposed subprojects are economically viable under the base case scenario 
and also under adverse changes in conditions, except in some cases. The adverse changes 
analyzed were: (i) a capital cost overrun of 10%, (ii) a 10% increase in the O&M cost, (iii) a 10% 
reduction in the benefits, and (iv) a year’s delay in the subproject benefits. The sensitivity 
analysis indicates that the proposed subprojects are most sensitive to delay in subproject 
benefits, but remain well above the economic opportunity cost of capital except in Namkheung.
